And then we introduced the Van

Historically, it's

And then that's an example

It's an example of a

there was then an extension

What's the force the Van

semi and infinite [? plates. ?]
And the potential is inversely

proportional to the separation,
D, between these two surfaces.

And this potential is-- you can say when

it goes to more negative. So it's attractive
potential and so attractive

force between the two surfaces. And on the top,
the constant here

is also called Hamaker constant. And it has-- it's
a physical region.

If you learn, say, if
you do a phase change, you'll probably say this has
a Hamaker constant before.

And [INAUDIBLE] that's the
Casimir force is dipole-dipole. This Van der Waals force is
dipole-dipole interaction.

And the extension of that
is the Casimir force. And the Casimir force
is, as I explained,

it was the idea that the
force between the two object,

1 and 2, and can be think
about that the energy stored

in this space between
1 and 2, the medium-- that's right--
could be a vacuum.

And when I think

learned that the quantization

one half h nu. And then how many modes you

in this space? And if each mode can turn

you do that summation
of the total energy. And you find out that
either of the two surface

gets closer to
each other, you're excluding modes so the

And so you have
attractive force. So that gave the quantum spin
to the Van der Waals force

interaction picture. And that was [? a ?]

[? jiggling ?] means what?

There's no temperature

So zero point has a fluctuation. And this fluctuating will
generate electromagnetic wave.

The electromagnetic waves
propagate to this side. And that will create
an interaction

between the two sides. So you basically [? solve ?]
Maxwell's equation.

And then the jiggling
is, again, connected with the so-called
fluctuation-dissipation theorem, so you can calculate
the force interaction

from electrodynamics
perspective. And that's a much
more generous theory.

So what you have is 1, 2, 3. And what you need is the

epsilon 1, which could be

it could be another material. And in fact, there is a--

if you do phase change,

you'll probably encounter--
how many of you have heard of disjoining pressure? Anybody has heard about that?

OK, yeah. Disjoining pressure is,
again, another concept that is encountered in

For example, if you consider the

so you have a corner, and the

But there could be another

And people say that's because

about this as a medium one. A vacuum is a medium, remember. Or say any space for
electromagnetic wave

is a medium. And that the liquid
film is medium 3. And whatever there is solid,

So I can calculate

And it turns out that in
some tests, most of the case

this is attractive. In some cases there,
the force in between could also be repulsive.

If it's a repulsive
force, then there actually will be a stable
layer of liquid that's

sustained on the surface.  If it's evaporation,
if it's a heating,

then if you have a liquid film,
you help your heat transfer. So there is this
disjointing pressure
